item.title: Policy In The Alleviation of The Achievement Gap: Head Start
item.dc:creator: tinahhong
item.content:encoded:
In Lyndon B. Johnson’s 1964 State of the Union Address, he shared his vision for a War on Poverty. As part of this, he planned to develop a program to prepare low-income children for elementary school. A major issue in the perpetuation of poverty is inequity in the quality of education, so Johnson appointed agencies and experts to develop child development programs to help low-income and disadvantaged communities provide better early childhood education. The transition from preschool to elementary school imposes diverse developmental challenges that include requiring the children to engage successfully with their peers outside the family network, adjust to the space of a classroom, and meet the expectations the school setting provides. Johnson’s large comprehensive program that tackled these issues eventually became known as the Head Start program. Head Start was intended to be a wide-ranging program that would provide low-income families resources to prepare their children for school. This was heavily influenced by the philosophy that children require holistic development. Therefore, the program was intended to address early learning, health, and parent involvement. Within childhood education, the program stressed many aspects of learning, including play, interactions with adults, and planned instruction. Alongside this, children would develop social skills by being around fellow students. To support health, the policy helped families access medical services. It also provided its own health screenings, nutritious meals, and mental health support. Lastly, to foster enriching family environments, the program would give parents guidance on how to reach their own goals, such as housing stability, continued education, and financial security. The program would also champion healthy parent-child relationships by advocating for parents to become involved in their child’s development. In order to successfully solve the problems of all low-income families, Head Start needed to provide services to minority and at-risk groups. For example, Head Start aimed to reach children of migrant and seasonal farm workers by creating services specifically targeted to them. This program included longer hours each day, but it lasted for a shorter period. Similarly, Head Start sought to help indigenous Americans by creating centers on reservations and to specifically find and target homeless children. Later on, policy makers expanded their reach through Early Head Start, which sought to address the problem of school-readiness at an even earlier age. This meant supporting child development beginning as early as birth. In order to facilitate these goals, Head Start planned to assign each child a Service Coordinator who would help assess the family’s situation and provide the required services. These early intervention services would help children receive tailored support. Originally, the Office of Economic Opportunity's (OEO’s) Community Action Program launched Project Head Start as an eight-week summer program through Head Start Child Development Centers in 1965. The program was led by Dr. Robert Cooke, a respected pediatrician, and Dr. Edward Zigler, a professor and psychologist at Yale. It was intended to help communities meet the needs of disadvantaged preschool children. The OEO implemented many of the other programs included in the Great Society plan, including VISTA and Job Corps. It received government funding to carry out its initiatives. However, this appropriation of funding was later ruled unconstitutional in 1973. Based on the success of the summer program, Congress authorized Head Start as a primarily part day, nine-month program. By 1965, Head Start organized the first school year programs. The following year it was authorized by Congress as a year–round program. In 1968, Head Start began funding a television series that would eventually become the show that all children know and love: Sesame Street. The Government Accountability Office labeled Project Head Start a success in child development, but the GAO also influenced Head Start’s evolution. By releasing a report that found challenges in parent engagement within the program, the GAO’s analysis influenced Head Start to improve policies on parent participation. The Office of Economic Opportunity is an agency in the Department of Commerce. Its major function during the War on Poverty was to innovate, experiment, and develop new approaches to the problems of poverty, so in 1969, after Project Head Start had generated substantial success, it was reassigned to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, in the Office of Child Development, within the Children's Bureau. In 1972, Congress amended the Economic Opportunity Act, mandating that at least 10 percent of Head Start’s national enrollment consist of handicapped children. Head Start collaborates with the Office of Education Bureau of Education for the Handicapped to fund offer technical assistance to Head Start teachers to help them work with handicapped children. The McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act of 2001 required Head Start to allow homeless children and families access to early childhood education. During the 2007 reauthorization, homeless children were included explicitly as subjects of the program. In response to public criticism about the positive benefits of Head Start fading out over time, as well as new scientific research emphasizing the importance of the first few years in child development, President Obama proposed a series of new investments during the 2013 State of the Union address that would establish access to high quality education for children between birth and the age of 5. These new investments included providing preschool for all, funding Early Head Start-Child Care partnerships, and expanding home visiting programs. Overtime, Head start is continually expanding. Head Start’s federal budget has consistently increased over the years, peaking at $10 billion as of 2019. Every few years, the standards that the program holds for students and teachers is elevated, and the types of services it provides diversifies. As the program continues to expand, statistics have shown that parents in the Head Start program report positive outcomes with their experience. A 2015 CCR Analytics survey, which reached 11,600 California Head Start parents, found that 90% of parents said Head Start aided them in finding a job and 99% reported that Head Start gave them key resources to assist their parenting. Evidently, parents see the beneficial impact of Head Start within their own families. However, further research on child outcomes is less clear-cut. A study using data from the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth (NLSY) found that children in Head Start have an increased probability of graduating from high school and going to college. It was also found to have long-term social-emotional effects, helping Head Start students increase their self-esteem and regulate their emotions in adulthood. However, these findings may be called into question. Because Head Start children are among the most impoverished in the United States, meaning that (everything else being equal) they would be expected to achieve less than other students. As a result, it’s difficult to compare children in the Head Start program to a control group. According to an article in The Atlantic, the only long-term study of the program, called the Head Start Impact Study, began following enrollees in 2002 and stayed with them through third grade. Researchers found that by third grade, all the academic advances the children had made during their Head Start year had faded (Monegau). It’s evident that research findings are often conflicting. One reason for Head Start’s struggles is that it doesn’t receive enough funding to entirely fulfill its mission. In 2014-15, only 41% of Head Start’s target population received its programs. Early Head Start, by comparison, reached only 3% of its population. Therefore, to reach all edible students, funding for Head Start and Early Head Start would need to increase enormously. Although, Head Start programs cost significantly less than comparable programs such as Perry Preschool and Carolina Abcedarian, so it provides more room for scaling if it were to receive additional funding. Although Head Start hasn’t been able to support all eligible students, it has  succeeded in reaching a wide range of students, eventually expanding to support minorities such as Native Americans, children with disabilities, homeless children, and migrant. This is incredibly important because minority groups are often at high-risk for poverty and discrimination, and they are easily ignored by government programs. Lastly, Head Start was founded to adapt to local situations, putting an emphasis on developing differently for different needs. However, Head Start still requires an extensive list of requirements for preschools. As a result, Head Start directors often report that they dedicate an exorbitant amount of time to document whether or not they comply with government regulations for preschools. Head Start is the largest comprehensive governmental program dedicated towards alleviating the achievement gap, and it has had a significant impact on thousands of families over the course of its development. Although it faces challenges, like insufficient funding and spending excess resources on administrative oversight, its programs ultimately promote educational equity among America’s most vulnerable children. Furthermore, its holistic approach has had positive effects on parents, providing families with the resources to support their children’s education. Moving forward, more research must be undertaken to determine areas in which the program can continually improve.    
Works Cited https://www.acf.hhs.gov/ohs/about/head-start http://www.child-encyclopedia.com/head-start-policy/according-experts/economic-impact-head-start https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/08/is-head-start-a-failure/494942/ https://www.brookings.edu/research/the-long-term-impact-of-the-head-start-program/ https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/blog/2015/05/18/day-history-creation-head-start https://www.nhsa.org/about-us/mission-vision-history https://eclkc.ohs.acf.hhs.gov/about-us/article/head-start-timeline https://www.thegravelygroup.com/resources/history-of-head-start/ https://hechingerreport.org/is-head-start-a-failure/

item.title: First Gen Growth Mindset: A Mini Memoir
item.dc:creator: tinahhong
item.content:encoded:
Please note that this memoir is very personal. The goal of my blog was not only for it to educate others, but for it to help me learn more about myself. Writing became therapeutic as it helped me understand my emotions, personality and values better. So please read with an open mind, and feel free to comment if you have any reactions or questions. Thanks :)
  While my teammates were always disappointed whenever their parents couldn’t make it to one of their games, I felt my heart accelerate and a rush of adrenaline course through my veins when I spotted my dad walk into the gym during warmups to sit in the bleachers behind our bench. He never sat with the rest of the team parents. Instead, he always sat closest to me or closest to the basket that our team was scoring in so that he was in the optimal spot to heckle me. From the moment that the ball tipped off he was already screaming in my ear. “Attack!” He barked whenever I ran down on the side of the floor closest to him. A grimace would spring up on my face whenever I heard him. I always tried to focus on the game and drown out the crowd, but his harsh voice pierced through the din of otherwise pleasant cheers. It became so unnerving that I ran up the side of the court furthest from him so that he wouldn’t scream across the gym. The things that he screamed at me ranged from annoying to downright terrifying. They were usually spoken in a mix of broken English or Chinese, and he relied on the fact that there weren’t many other Chinese people on any basketball team to scream insults that he thought only I could understand. “Nǐ zài bú dé fēn wǒ jiù huì dǎ sǐ nǐ!” I nearly stopped mid-sprint when his words finally processed through my brain. My face unconsciously contorted in an expression of horror and embarrassment. I really hoped that none of the people in the gym understood Chinese, because hearing a parent scream death threats at their fifth-grade children during a basketball game is probably a little bit concerning. Unlike the other teammates who went up to their parents right after games, I would always take care to trail behind my dad a few steps as we left the gym and walked to the parked car. The parking lot was quiet while my teammates trudged away after a disappointing loss. As my dad entered into the driver’s seat of our blue sedan, I lingered outside to soak in my last few seconds of quiet before ducking into the backseat with my little sister, Aimee. Aimee and I sat stiffly in the backseat, the passenger seat besides our dad empty. I tried to avert my gaze from the rear view mirror, staring aimlessly out the window to avoid looking at the scowl ingrained on my dad’s face. But my eyes inevitably gravitated towards the mirror in anticipation of the upcoming lecture. Sure enough, I eventually saw his lips twitch in the mirror as he cleared his throat. “Tinah, how many shots you take last game.” I shut my eyes and took a deep breath: “I don’t know,” I exclaimed on the exhale. My response was almost inaudible. “Three! You only take three shots.” My dad’s challenging voice crescendoed. My fist curled shut. “You never take enough shot, how are you supposed to score if you only take three shot? . . .” He  continued slandering me, and I knew that nothing that he said was going to be productive, so I tried to drown his voice out by focusing on counting the cars that we passed by. 1 . . . 2, 3 . . 4 . . . . . 5, 6, 7, 8, . . As I juggled my count in my head, my focus was shattered by my dad’s continually rising voice: “Next time if you don’t take more than ten shot, then I beat you for sure.” Aimee flinched. A few months ago, I might’ve flinched too, but I’d grown so accustomed to hearing his threats that I went right back to counting cars. Aimee sat stiffly next to me, not responding to any of this except for little, almost imperceptible sniffles that she tried to hide. She knew that it was only a matter of time before dad came at her instead. So even before he was through with me, she was already wiping snot on her jersey in anticipation of her upcoming punishment. She glared at our dad through bloodshot eyes, a defense mechanism that I recognized all too clearly. It was an attempt to free her from the helplessness we felt, an attempt to wrestle back shreds of our dignity. I yearned to diffuse the tension in the car, but flashbacks to escalated voices and physical anger warn me against wasting my breath.   Aimee and I dread the car ride home from basketball games. It’s long been associated with us cowering from our father as he screams at us for hours for not making enough points. His disappointment and anger is never supplemented with any real feedback on how to do so though, so all I heard was that maybe I wasn’t trying hard enough, because, according to our dad, if I really wanted to, I should’ve been able to score more. As much as I knew that the mere will to score doesn’t translate to the ability to do so, I also knew that failure to perform to the standards set for me would result in a barrage of angry attacks and threats. During games, instead of focusing on the next play, I became bogged down by moments when I messed up or when I missed shots. My dad’s demands to “make your layups!” as if I was deliberately trying to miss them or something, constantly echoed in the back of my mind. His words jostled out the productive voices of my coaches, my teammates, and myself. My fear of him led me to play timidly and passively. There were a few moments throughout elementary and middle school that I believed that my dad was right, and that I just didn’t want to score enough. As much as I tried to ice out his criticism, as much as I slowly built up walls to protect myself from my dad’s scalding comments, his attitude consumed me. My self-esteem became inextricably intertwined with success and achievement. Failure to score enough points wasn’t met by feedback and encouragement to do better next time, but by loathing and punishment. The do-or-die incentive that my dad posed caused the prospect of failure to terrify me. It caused my failures to define me, and in order to avoid failure, I developed risk-aversion and low self-esteem that continued to plague me throughout my high school years. 9 . . . 10, 11 . . . . . 12 . . . the cars outside were starting to swerve and blur—a combination of my dad’s angry swerving and the frustrated tears brimming up at the bottom of my eyes that I desperately tried to blink away.
  My heart started to pound before I even walked into the classroom. Madison, my friend I walk to first period with every day, turns the doorknob and opens the heavy wooden door, exposing the imposing, bleak interior of room 251. The seats are arranged in a big circle so that everyone can easily stare at you when you talk. The front of the classroom is where the dusty chalkboard with the discussion question of the day sits. There are two seats in front of it. One for the teacher, and to the left, the assigned seat which I awkwardly plop down into. My face heats up immediately as I become hyper aware of how everyone will be staring at the board above my head. “Morning, everyone,” my teacher introduces, while her hand glides punctually over the board, “I hope you enjoyed the reading last night. Today we will be discussing the question of whether or not people should change themselves to make other people more comfortable around them. “Remember,” she says after a pause, “everyone will be participating today.” I look up from the wooden table, upon which I’ve already left an angry, sweaty imprint of my burning hands. I turn to look at the question scribbled on the worn out, green board. The harsh yellow writing burns in my mind. I frantically search for any possible arguments. “Spencer, start us off,” I hear from my right. “I think in this example, a black man should not have to whistle constantly while walking down the sidewalk. Although it may make him look a little less imposing, the fact that, uh, others stereotype him is not his problem, rather, it is up to them to confront their biases.” “I agree,” Patrick chips in, “It isn’t just to expect him to change because of what others think about him. There is nothing about him besides the stereotypes associated with his race and statute that make others afraid of him.” Spencer and Patrick sit in the same side of the room and they never hesitate to offer their opinions. I’ve always wished I had their boldness and confidence to take over any conversation, but I can never dismiss the thought of what my classmates will think of what I have to say, and this muddles my thoughts about the topic at hand. I grasp at the strings floating around in my mind, furrowing my brows as I struggle to form a coherent thought. I have a few ideas, but I should probably form an exact script and run through it four times in my head before I raise my hand. “On the contrary, I think sometimes there are serious situations in which doing something to try to alleviate other people’s anxieties may actually be warranted,” counters Keyler, the boy sitting across from me, “as much as it sucks, imagine a girl walking down an alley alone at night, and a guy is walking towards her. The reality of our society is that the girl has a right to be afraid, and in that situation it may make sense for the guy to feel obligated to give her space, or do something else to make himself appear less threatening.” It’s a good point, I’ll admit, and I could add on, but if I open up my mouth, nonsense would spew out of my shaking lungs, and I’ll say something dumb. I hold off on raising my hand, until, one by one, my teacher has checked off everyone else’s name on her wooden clipboard. In the last three minutes of class, my teacher looks at me, her usual bored and stoic face is plastered with an expression of pity. “Tinah,” she says, “you’re the only one who hasn’t talked, what do you think?” Everyone’s head swivels and fixates on me. The room begins to tilt and lurch. My dry mouth opens, closes. I feel like a fish out of water, I can barely breathe, and my only thought is how my heart is pounding so hard that it’s probably audible to the person next to me. I clear my throat, hesitate, until unscripted words tumble out. “I think, uh, I think it wouldn’t be fair to expect people to, uh, . . . gionwlkg . . . owk . . .”   It’s over. I sink down into my chair as the bell rings. I survived, and although I had spoken with a nice, unintended vibrato, I didn’t pass out like I thought I would. Still, to this day, I can’t recall a single coherent thought that I said. Despite my friends in that class telling me that no one was actually paying attention to the discussion, I believed that anything I said would be used for others to judge and put me down. Because for me, the high expectations that have always been placed on me, as well as my father’s reprimanding voice always surfacing from the back of my mind, incites within me the urge to cower instead of stand and fight in times of performance. The world was never a supportive place that I could trust, but instead, everyone was cold, calculating, and unforgiving—any mistake that I made would be permanently ingrained in the memories of others, because it for sure haunted my dad’s and mine. My fear of judgement constrained me to the point where I developed physical symptoms of anxiety that plagued me in my sophomore year of english class. Speaking up opened up windows for others to see my brain’s thought process, and I cursed my body for literally shaking out of fear of this vulnerability. Like the people who can command a classroom and not be afraid to be the loudest voice, there are also the ball hogs who can step into a gym and not care at all what the other people in the gym think about them. I was never one of those people. That fact was made abundantly clear that summer. My family and I had driven all the way down to my hometown in Minnesota, and after a night spent tightening the pillows I had placed over my head to try blocking out the train-like roar of my dad’s loud snoring until 4 AM, I was sluggishly running up the familiar court of Jefferson High School at the tipoff of our 8 AM game. A few plays into the game, the shrill shriek of the ref’s whistle pierced my ears. Our team jogged to the bench to gather in a huddle. As I jostled through the throng of players, I emerged to the front of the huddle, where I saw my coach’s finger directly pointed an inch away from my face. “You,” Stan said, “stop passing up shots and shoot the damn ball, you were open that last play.” My eyebrows raised. I knew which play he was talking about, and while I suppose I was a little open, I hadn’t thought that the three would’ve been the best shot for the team. “Or just drive the ball,” he continued, “you’re one of the best players on the team, stop giving the ball up or I’ll sit you out.” The ref blew his whistle again. As we left the huddle, I felt two thumps on my back. I turned. “Hey, you got it,” Jenna said. I nodded and smiled at her, before taking the court again. We run up and down the court again for the last few minutes until the end of the half, and I made sure to take one more open shot like Stan had told me to do. As the last twelve seconds of the half counted down, I had the ball again at the top of the key. “Take her!” Stan shouts from the opposite side of the court. With my first step, I boldly challenged my defender, blowing right past her. With the basket in sight, I prepared to take the final shot. But I hesitated, looking wildly helpless. It was then when the familiar voices invaded my head, consuming me with doubt that overrode my instinct to score. I stopped and threw the ball away to my teammate, Claire, who was forced to throw up a contested shot. As the last second ticked away, her shot smacked off the backboard as hard as my coach smacked his head. Running in to the huddle at halftime, I could already tell from Stan’s deadset face that he was not happy. “Ok Tinah, what’d I just tell you? I know you heard me telling you to ‘take her,’ but you passed the ball. You threw the ball away again! And look what kinda shot we got. I can’t play you if you’re gonna keep playing like this. So the starters are starting the second half, except Jenna, you take Tinah’s spot.” As the new starters took the court, I was too shocked to even cry. I turned to join the bench, and I heard my teammates apologizing, trying to console me, or saying that Stan was being dumb, but I quietly looked onwards, walking doggedly to the end of the bench.   “We lost because Stan didn’t put you in,” Mr. Khan said. “If only he wasn’t so stubborn,” Ms. Murray echoed. I didn’t really know what to say. I hadn’t yet decided whether or not what Stan did was justified. All I knew was that I was shocked and frustrated at having had to keep the bench warm for a whole half. I opened my mouth to reply to my teammates’ parents, but I quickly shut it again when I saw Stan beckoning from behind them. It was hard to hear, especially after we lost, but Stan had good intentions for benching me. “I’ve been coaching you for three years now, and I’ve seen how good you are. But that right there was embarrassing. You play like you aren’t one of the best players on the court.” “But, but I’m uh, I’m not one of, uh . . .” Stan shakes his head incredulously, his eyes narrowing, “you dominate in practice. But you don’t show out in games. You’re might as well just sit on the bench if you’re gonna play passively, because you aren’t contributing like I know you can. All you do is, like, run up and down the fucking court.” “But I don’t usually take contested shots-” “You take them in practice and you always knock ‘em down. How will you ever know if you can make them in games if you never try?” Stan was beginning to talk more and more heatedly, his words were accompanied by rapid gesticulation. “But-” “Don’t but me,” he scoffs with a chilly laugh, “you have no excuses to make. All I want is for you to play like I know you can. I want you to have a demanding presence. Every time you step on the court, you should be the loudest one in the gym — the player that every opponent and coach knows and worries about. I know you can do that.” I shut my mouth then, and stood stiffly in place, nodding earnestly as he continued to lecture. Stan’s dose of tough love made me realize that it wasn’t selflessness that made me pass the ball to Claire, but fear. I feared how I would look if I missed a shot; I feared how my classmates would react if I said something dumb; I feared what others would think if I stepped out of my comfort zone. By never facing my fear of vulnerability and failure, I would never reach my fullest potential. I realized that he really was trying to do what was best for me when he benched me. “Thank you,” I say as he turns to leave.
  John sits hunched over on the curb next to me, shaking, his head cradled in his hands. “Are you cold?” I ask, wrapping my coat around him. “No, I just can’t . . . can’t stop shaking,” he musters through his sniffles. My best friend’s energetic and intense demeanor that I’ve grown to love is gone, replaced with the trembling figure breaking down next to me. “It’s gonna be okay,” I whisper, trying to convince both of us. “I’m just going through a tough time, and n-none of my guy friends try to understand,” “Well, I’m always here for you.” “That’s why I always ask you how you’re doing, ‘cause I wanna know that you’re okay.” “I already told you, I’m fine.” “Fine doesn’t mean anything though” he protests between quick shallow breaths, “that’s just a cop-out.” “But like, I literally don’t feel anything, it’s just an average day,” I insist. “Tinah, I don’t think you’re just fine, I think you’re afraid of finding out how you really feel.” The headlights of his ride finally find us. John gets up, wipes away his tears, and leaves me alone with the unforgiving moon, his final words swirling through my mind.   Later, I tried to gauge how I really felt. Every day after school, I had a basketball practice or game, and when that ended I went straight to another person’s house to tutor. Then I would eat, shower, start homework, write essays if I had time, and prepare for the next day. I kept myself busy every second and I was so focused on my work that I didn’t even have time to dwell on how much I had to do, or how much it was stressing me out. But something else I didn’t make time to do was check up on my best friend. Because while I was hiding my emotions, John was feeling his fully, and I failed to realize that. Even while he was crying, shaking, and curled up on the curb, he was stronger than I was. He showed strength by confronting his pain straight on and by being completely vulnerable and human in his weakness. Sometime along the many years of angry car rides, I’ve learned how to tame my emotions and harness my tears. Instead of being vulnerable and real with my raw emotions, I conditioned myself to believe that despite anything I may be feeling at a specific moment, everything would eventually work out. This sentiment has allowed me to almost transcend my worries and doubts. But I hadn’t realized that it had gotten to a point where instead of healthily being in tune with my thoughts and emotions, and then transcending them, I was blatantly ignoring them and pretending that they weren’t there. I numbed myself to stress and anxiety as an unhealthy way to cope with these negative emotions, but in doing so, I also became numb to my joy and happiness. I was robbing myself of experiencing the full range of human emotions. In my efforts to not feel anything, I risk being dangerously complacent and out of sync with who I am. The purpose of feeling is to provoke change or provide positive feedback. By feeling stressed about being busy, I allow myself to settle down and reprioritize. By not repressing my dad’s rebuking reprimands to the back of my mind, and instead feeling gross and indignant at the way that my dad treats my sister and I, I gain the strength to confront him. By feeling angry and frustrated when I get benched for a half, I am inspired to redirect that into playing assertively. By feeling empathy and sadness for John on the night that he broke down, I reflect and change so that I can free myself to fully feel all of these raw emotions again.
